DOC.HEAD: Security Council Has to Choose Between Two Panamanian Governments
Eds: UPDATES throughout with debate delayed while Security Council decides which government to recognize.
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council delayed its debate on Panama on Wednesday while trying to decide which government is legitimate: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's regime or the U.S.-installed administration. The United States, with the help of other Western members, stalled the council while pressing for recognition of a new U.N. ambassador to be appointed by the fledgling Panamanian government of Guillermo Endara. Endara was widely believed to have won the presidency in Panama's national elections May 7. But Noriega, the military leader, canceled the balloting before results were announced. The overnight invasion by U.S. military forces ousted Noriega and installed Endara as president. Endara was expected to appoint Eduardo Vallarino, a Panamanian businessman in self-imposed exile in the United States, as its U.N. ambassador, said diplomats. Panama has no ambassador currently accredited at the United Nations. The previous permanent representative, Leonardo Kam, was promoted to foreign minister, and no one had taken his place. Noriega's government is reportedly trying to have its ambassador to the European Community, Merla Bellavita, accredited as its U.N. ambassador. The Security Council was originally to hold its emergency meeting Wednesday morning, said officials at the Mission of Colombia, which currently chairs the council. Diplomats speaking on condition of anonymity said, however, that wrangles over which Panamanian ambassador was representing the legitimate government delayed the meeting. Council members held meetings among themselves to decide how to proceed. The Security Council is faced with having to decide which foreign minister represents Panama's legitimate government: Noriega's appointee, Kam, or whomever Endara appoints. In an afternoon news conference in Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Endara is moving to appoint ambassadors to Washington and the United Nations. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering said the United States acted in self--defense when it sent its military forces to Panama to oust Noriega. Alejandro Serrano Caldera, the ambassador of Nicaragua, which called for an emergency Security Council meeting, retorted that ``the United States has no legal or ethical right to intervene in other countries' affairs.'' Speaking in Spanish through an interpreter, Serrano Caldera said ``We want the council to call for an immediate withdrawal of the U.S. troops.'' Pickering told reporters outside the council that the United States had the right to intervene under Article 51 of the U.N. Charter, ``which provides for the use of armed force to defend a country, to defend our interests and our people, it's the so-called `self-defense article.''' Panamanian soldiers shot and killed a U.S. Marine officer at a roadblock on Saturday night. Panama's declaration last week that a ``state of war'' existed with the United States and ``the attacks on our citizens over the weekend are several of the things which the president has cited which required us to move in self-defense,'' Pickering said. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush ordered U.S. troops to seize Noriega and bring him to the United States for trial on federal drug charges. Baker informed Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the military moves by telephone at 2 a.m. Wednesday, said the U.N. chief's spokesman, Francois Giuliani. Perez de Cuellar is ``extremely concerned'' about the crisis, said Giuliani. Panama has repeatedly come before the Security Council to complain of allegedly provocative U.S. military maneuvers that it said were intended to lay the groundwork for an invasion to topple the government. Panama claimed during council debates in April and August that the United States is trying to provoke confrontations in order to keep control of the Panama Canal. Under a 1977 treaty, the United States is to turn over control of the canal to Panama at the end of 1999.
